Award.AwardTitle: 19th Annual Symposium of the NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellows
Award.AbstractNarration: This award will provide support for the attendees and invited speakers for the nineteenth Annual Symposium of the NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellows, to be held remotely in February 2021. The purpose of the Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowships (AAPF) Program is to support integrated research and education activities at the postdoctoral level to better prepare its fellows for positions of distinction and leadership in the scientific community. The Annual Symposium provides a forum for the Fellows to discuss their research and education projects while increasing their visibility within the astronomy and astrophysics community. The Symposium represents a key component of the AAPF Program, and it is a very effective mechanism to facilitate the transfer of knowledge and experience that the Fellows have acquired through their postdoctoral training. <br/><br/>As with previous symposia in this series, the 2021 AAPF Symposium will promote interactions among astronomers with diverse research interests and backgrounds. By creating a forum in which discussions can occur across traditional research boundaries, the Symposium will provide Fellows the opportunity to gain new insights and pursue interdisciplinary collaborations. The Symposium will also provide a venue for discussing major issues that are important to early-career astronomers. In addition, the Symposium will (1) provide a forum to discuss integrated research and education activities, (2) facilitate collaborations between Fellows on both research and education, and (3) provide greater exposure for the Fellows and the AAPF Program within the astronomical community.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded the 2021 NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Fellowship Program Symposium, which took place with a virtual format on Zoom, as well as live streamed on YouTube. There were 48 registered attendees who joined the symposium on Zoom, with upward of 100 daily views of the livestream on YouTube. The meeting featured 17 15-minute talks from Fellows, who shared the results from their research and education program. Two invited keynote speakers presented one-hour talks: Dr. Jane Rigby (NASA Goddard) gave a talk ?Science with the James Webb Space Telescope? about future research opportunities with NASA?s next flagship mission, and Dr. Molly Simon (Arizona State) presented ?A New Model for Bringing Citizen Science to the Undergraduate Classroom? which focused on opportunities with the online Zooniverse project. We also hosted two panel discussions with experts from the field. The ?Diversity & Equity in Education and Public Outreach Panel? addressed how to effectively engage equitably with diverse audiences in our public outreach activities. The ?Future Careers for Astronomy Postdocs Panel? featured former astronomy postdocs (most former AAPF Fellows) who now work in a range of careers, from professors in large research institutions and smaller teaching-focused colleges, to scientists doing service for larger missions/surveys and data scientists in the private sector, this Q&A provided guidance for how current fellows can navigate their future careers down these various pathways.
